message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of pericarditis, which is commonly associated with SLE. The EKG findings for pericarditis include PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations. Prolonged PR intervals with normal QRS complexes are associated with AV block, peaked T waves with flattened P waves are associated with hyperkalemia, and irregularly irregular QRS complexes with no P waves are associated with atrial fibrillation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms and signs of pericarditis, which can occur as a complication of SLE. EKG changes that can be seen in pericarditis include diffuse ST elevations and PR segment depressions. Option A is incorrect as prolonged PR interval is not commonly seen in pericarditis. Option B is incorrect as peaked T waves and flattened P waves are usually seen in hyperkalemia. Option C is incorrect as irregularly irregular QRS complexes with no P waves are seen in atrial fibrillation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including pleuritic chest pain that improves when leaning forward, suggest pericarditis. The rise in jugular venous pressure during inspiration also indicates pericarditis. Among the options, PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations are the most characteristic EKG pattern for pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms - cough, pleuritic chest pain, improved posture, and increased jugular venous pressure during inspiration - suggest pericarditis. PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations are commonly seen in pericarditis. All other options are not associated with pericarditis. Since the patient has SLE, which can cause pericarditis, it is important to consider this diagnosis as a potential cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pericarditis, which can also be caused by SLE. The most likely EKG pattern to be seen in this patient is PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations, which are characteristic of pericarditis. The other options do not match the typical EKG findings in pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest pericarditis, which is common in patients with SLE. PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations are the most common EKG findings in acute pericarditis. Prolonged PR interval with normal QRS complexes is seen in atrioventricular block. Peaked T waves with flattened P waves suggest hyperkalemia. Irregularly irregular QRS complexes with no P waves suggest atrial fibrillation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest pericarditis, a common complication of SLE. The EKG pattern most likely to be seen in this patient with pericarditis is PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations. Option (A) is associated with first-degree heart block, (B) is associated with hyperkalemia, and (C) is associated with atrial fibrillation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute pericarditis. The rise in jugular venous pressure during inspiration suggests cardiac tamponade. EKG findings in acute pericarditis typically include PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations. Options A, B, and C are not associated with acute pericarditis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest pericarditis, which can be seen in patients with SLE. The rise in jugular venous pressure during inspiration indicates right heart failure, which can also be caused by pericarditis. The most likely EKG pattern seen in pericarditis is PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations. Option A is incorrect because prolonged PR intervals are seen in AV block. Option B is incorrect because peaked T waves and flattened P waves are seen in hyperkalemia. Option C is incorrect because irregularly irregular QRS complexes with no P waves are seen in atrial fibrillation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest pericarditis, which can be seen in patients with SLE. The pain improving when the patient leans forward is a classic finding. The rise in jugular venous pressure during inspiration suggests constrictive pericarditis. The EKG pattern associated with acute pericarditis is PR depressions and diffuse ST elevations, which is the correct answer. The other options are associated with other conditions, such as hyperkalemia (peaked T waves with flattened P waves) and atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular QRS complexes with no P waves).
